stream_context.summary: Kaze prototypes the “inside-the-pyramid” sub-area for Course 14, focusing on how to make an 8-red-coin maze that feels overwhelming at first but ‘clicks’ once the player understands its structure.  He also shows an off-stream “saw area” for Course 15, fixes coins and discusses global-coin design, a new BLJ bug, and marketing matters with Biobak.

development_findings.summary: Course 14 now needs only two sub-areas; Kaze is blocking out the pyramid interior that will hold the red-coin mission.
development_findings.quote: “There’s only two areas missing in the papercraft level and then Course 14 is complete.”

development_findings.summary: Design goal: a maze that confuses initially but quickly ‘resolves’ through landmarks (large central cliff, visible entrances) and a single main path with eight shortcut spurs holding the red coins.
development_findings.quote: “I want the player to be like, ‘Oh, this is such a weird cave system,’ and then realise, ‘Ah, this is how it works.’”

development_findings.summary: Shortcuts are intentionally one-way (drops, trapdoors, sliding shafts) so ‘follow-the-left-wall’ logic fails and players must think about layout.
He rejected heavier puzzle mechanics (password rooms, mirrors, colour memory) as too technical or out-of-tone with RTYI’s design ethos.
development_findings.quote: “A puzzle like that is very much against the rest of the design of RTY.”

development_findings.summary: Enemies will stay thematically on bombs & womps; ants were deemed off-theme for the cardboard pyramid interior.
Kaze finished a Course 15 ‘saw area’ off-stream; Zeina test-played and struggled, flagging it as maybe the hardest section so far.
development_findings.quote: “When Zeina played, she had trouble beating it, but I think the difficulty is fine considering it’s Course 15.”

development_findings.summary: He discovered a new backwards-long-jump exploit created by the ground-pound-dive move and marked it as critical to fix.
development_findings.quote: “That’s a new bug… Apparently you can now BLJ. That’s a very important bug to fix.”

development_findings.summary: He is experimenting with dropping the 100-coin star in favour of a global coin counter shared across stages, but hasn’t settled on presentation (starting each level with coins, 4-digit HUD, etc.).
A Course 1–only public demo is planned once polishing of that level is done.
development_findings.quote: “There will be another demo of just Course 1.”

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s core design philosophy favours ‘implicit puzzles’ where comprehension emerges naturally rather than explicit logic challenges.
context_findings.quote: “I want this to be more like confusion and then the confusion resolves… without really thinking about it you suddenly understand it.”

context_findings.summary: He values Majora’s Mask-style world-building over pure dungeon chains, citing it as inspiration for RTYI’s pacing.
context_findings.quote: “What I really like about Zelda is all the in-between, and Majora’s Mask’s formula is perfect.”

context_findings.summary: Financial openness: roughly $900 YouTube revenue this month / $10 k yearly; family living costs ≈ $2.8 k per month; exploring new revenue like Twitter ads.
Lighthearted anxiety about Nintendo legal action remains (“If Nintendo ever completely sues me maybe I need to start an OnlyFans”).

biobak.summary: Joined brainstorm on pyramid ideas and marketing; suggested tweet-scheduling after noticing low analytics.
biobak.quote: “The Twitter post yesterday… if you don’t post at a certain time of day, no one sees it.”

biobak.summary: Gave visual feedback that the Styrofoam texture might read poorly and proposed stapled-paper cardboard instead.

zeina.summary: Play-tested the Course 15 saw section and her difficulty demonstrated it may be too punishing for average players.

key_stories.title: Designing a Maze that Teaches Itself
key_stories.summary: Kaze wrestles with how to make the pyramid interior feel labyrinthine yet ultimately readable. Multiple approaches (colour coding, mirrored halves, footstep decals) are weighed before settling on a single main path with one-way shortcut drops holding red coins.
key_stories.challenge: Create an engaging red-coin maze that isn’t frustrating.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed landmarks, rejected over-puzzly mechanics, mapped eight shortcut placements, and planned spikes, doors, and trap-drop mechanics.
key_stories.outcome: A workable block-out with coin and enemy plans; texturing/polishing to come.
key_stories.key_quote: “I want the confusion to resolve because you understand it; from then on it’s not a maze anymore.”

key_stories.title: Saw Area Difficulty Spike
key_stories.summary: Off-stream Kaze finished a saw-blade platform section for Course 15.  Zeina’s test run showed even skilled players may fail it, sparking debate over acceptable end-game difficulty.
key_stories.challenge: Balance Course 15’s hardest star without alienating players.
key_stories.process: Implemented timer-based saw platforms and colour-coded pieces; solicited Zeina’s feedback.
key_stories.outcome: Left as-is for now, but flagged as a concern.
key_stories.key_quote: “She didn’t really have a shot at beating it, so that’s why I feel like it’s a little difficult.”

key_stories.title: Accidental Return of BLJ
key_stories.summary: A new movement option inadvertently re-enabled Mario 64’s infamous BLJ exploit.
key_stories.challenge: Prevent legacy glitches from resurfacing after adding custom moves.
key_stories.process: Noticed mid-stream, identified C-value timing as probable cause.
key_stories.outcome: Marked for urgent fix before next build.
key_stories.key_quote: “Interesting. That’s a very important bug to fix.”

key_stories.title: Debating a Global Coin Economy
key_stories.summary: Kaze questions whether the traditional 100-coin star fits RTYI, floating ideas such as persistent coins and four-digit HUDs.
key_stories.challenge: Modernise coin collection while keeping players informed.
key_stories.process: Chat brainstorming (start levels with coins, boat-ticket tutorial, HUD tweaks).
key_stories.outcome: No final decision; noted for future design pass.

open_questions.topic: Final layout and readability of the pyramid maze
open_questions.context: Kaze has a rough block-out and competing ideas (one-way drops, colour hints, landmark cliff) but hasn’t chosen the exact mechanic that will make the confusion ‘click’.
questions: Which landmark or rule ultimately makes the maze self-explanatory?
Will colour coding survive performance limits?
How will one-way shortcuts be visually telegraphed?

open_questions.topic: Global coin system vs. classic 100-coin star
open_questions.context: He floated several UI and onboarding approaches but no decision was taken.
questions: How will global coins affect pacing and shop mechanics?

open_questions.context: Zeina’s struggle suggests some late-game stars may overshoot target difficulty.
questions: What metrics or tester pool does the team use to decide final difficulty?
Will there be adjustable difficulty options or mid-star checkpoints?
How does feedback from Zeina and the community translate into concrete changes?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a Course 1-only demo and joked about a ‘war level’ release ‘tomorrow’, but timelines are unclear.
questions: What content will the next public demo include and when?
What milestones gate a full release?
How does the team handle marketing around demos?

open_questions.context: Kaze half-joked about Nintendo legal action.
questions: Has the team taken any concrete steps (disclaimers, distribution methods) to avoid takedowns?
What is the contingency plan if Nintendo intervenes?
